data.text:
@HallwayOrchard @WorkSafeNB Thanks for the info.  I hope teachers are getting help and feeling supported. 
I imagine if I was a teacher, I would want to know what my options were.  Especially if I had a vulnerable family member at home or risk factors myself or if I was over age 50.
@sharla_cfm @WorkSafeNB Some provinces, such as BC, have also included Covid in their workers compensation legislation as an "occupational disease" in some circumstances. https://t.co/K7jexNmgOa

@sharla_cfm @WorkSafeNB Further, if Covid is a "biological agent" which negatively affects  health or wellbeing, any employee asked to perform work in a situation where they will be unprotected has a legislated right to refuse under the OHS Act. https://t.co/f4IyjLOOpl

@sharla_cfm According to the @WorkSafeNB website, Covid is considered biological agent, protections against which are legislated in the OHS Act.
I've reached out to them to ask if the requirement for employers to report Covid exposures will cease Mar 14 but have not received a response yet. https://t.co/2OdyMKux9B
@HallwayOrchard What is Work Safe NB's take on this?  Are teachers actually required to go into an unsafe workplace where they are at high risk of Covid infection, or otherwise lose their jobs??
@ThePracticalEsc @HallwayOrchard Or you have the intellectual vigor of a rock and cant discern basic math.
@OwenH_c137 @HallwayOrchard The literature from school district and early learning is always in F for temp

@ASD_South @HallwayOrchard What people are saying is this graphic doesn't follow the science of disease transmission, and is putting vulnerable students and vulnerable family members at home at risk. This is a justified anxiety for people who have at risk people at home.
@HallwayOrchard it isn't deadly anymore.  consider treatment for your anxiety
@ASD_South @HallwayOrchard Shame on the district and the fools in charge. You should be there for the children not for the clown in charge
